p: Our data also showed low CHIKV incidence rates (0.55–9.38/1000), in comparison with those reported from Kaffrine (with an incidence rate of 35.3%), Senegal in 1996–1997 [ 3] and on the Maldive islands (65.2/1000) [ 36]. This observation may be explained by the low density of the human population in Kedougou, which is 8 people/km 2 and probably not sufficient for human-mosquito-human CHIKV transmission. Previous studies showed that human population densities of approximately 3000–7000/km 2 are needed to produce CHIKV outbreaks [ 37]. It is also likely that only severe cases attend healthcare centers and clinics, and the asymptomatic forms of the disease—which is believed to be a vast majority of cases—were missed by the recruitment process used in this investigation.
